column1: 14:00|"two o’clock in the afternoon"|"ONE JANUARY DAY
column2: THIRTY years ago
column3: the little town of Hanover
column4: anchored on a windy Nebraska tableland
column5: was trying not to be blown away. A mist of fine snowflakes was curling and eddying about the cluster of low drab buildings huddled on the gray prairie
column6: under a gray sky. The dwelling-houses were set about haphazard on the tough prairie sod; some of them looked as if they had been moved in overnight
column7: and others as if they were straying off by themselves
column8: headed straight for the open plain. None of them had any appearance of permanence
column9: and the howling wind blew under them as well as over them. The main street was a deeply rutted road
column11: which ran from the squat red railway station and the grain “elevator” at the north end of the town to the lumber yard and the horse pond at the south end. On either side of this road straggled two uneven rows of wooden buildings; the general merchandise stores
column16: the post-office. The board sidewalks were gray with trampled snow
column17: but at two o’clock in the afternoon the shopkeepers
column19: were keeping well behind their frosty windows. The children were all in school
column20: and there was nobody abroad in the streets but a few rough-looking countrymen in coarse overcoats
column21: with their long caps pulled down to their noses. Some of them had brought their wives to town
column22: and now and then a red or a plaid shawl flashed out of one store into the shelter of another. At the hitch-bars along the street a few heavy work-horses
column24: shivered under their blankets. About the station everything was quiet
column25: for there would not be another train in until night."|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column1: ap 04:00|"four o’clock"|"Although it was only four o’clock
column2: the winter day was fading. The road led southwest
column3: toward the streak of pale
column4: watery light that glimmered in the leaden sky. The light fell upon the two sad young faces that were turned mutely toward it: upon the eyes of the girl
column5: who seemed to be looking with such anguished perplexity into the future; upon the sombre eyes of the boy
column6: who seemed already to be looking into the past. The little town behind them had vanished as if it had never been
column7: had fallen behind the swell of the prairie
column8: and the stern frozen country received them into its bosom. The homesteads were few and far apart; here and there a windmill gaunt against the sky
column9: a sod house crouching in a hollow. But the great fact was the land itself
column10: which seemed to overwhelm the little beginnings of human society that struggled in its sombre wastes. It was from facing this vast hardness that the boy’s mouth had become so bitter; because he felt that men were too weak to make any mark here
column11: that the land wanted to be let alone
column12: to preserve its own fierce strength

column1: > 12:00|"A little past noon"|"EMIL REACHED HOME A little past noon
column2: and when he went into the kitchen Alexandra was already seated at the head of the long table
column3: having dinner with her men
column4: as she always did unless there were visitors. He slipped into his empty place at his sister’s right. The three pretty young Swedish girls who did Alexandra’s housework were cutting pies
column5: refilling coffee-cups
column6: placing platters of bread and meat and potatoes upon the red tablecloth
column7: and continually getting in each other’s way between the table and the stove. To be sure they always wasted a good deal of time getting in each other’s way and giggling at each other’s mistakes. But
column8: as Alexandra had pointedly told her sisters-in-law
column9: it was to hear them giggle that she kept three young things in her kitchen; the work she could do herself
column10: if it were necessary. These girls
column11: with their long letters from home
column14: afforded her a great deal of entertainment
column15: and they were company for her when Emil was away at school."|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column1: ap 06:00|six|"Marie hurried away to make his coffee. When she came back
column2: he was fast asleep. She sat down and looked at him for a long while
column3: very thoughtfully. When the kitchen clock struck six she went out to get supper
column4: closing the door gently behind her. She was always sorry for Frank when he worked himself into one of these rages
column5: and she was sorry to have him rough and quarrelsome with his neighbors. She was perfectly aware that the neighbors had a good deal to put up with
column6: and that they bore with Frank for her sake."|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column1: ap 05:00|"five o’clock"|"“Why don’t he go to work like the rest of us did? His farm in the  Elbe valley
column2: indeed! Ain’t he got plenty brothers and sisters? It’s his mother’s farm
column3: and why don’t he stay at home and help her? Haven’t I seen his mother out in the morning at five o’clock with her ladle and her big bucket on wheels
column4: putting liquid manure on the cabbages? Don’t I know the look of old Eva Shabata’s hands? Like an old horse’s hoofs they are—and this fellow wearing gloves and rings! Engaged
column5: indeed! You aren’t fit to be out of school
column6: and that’s what’s the matter with you. I will send you off to the Sisters of the Sacred Heart in St. Louis
column7: and they will teach you some sense

column1: ~ 19:30|"about half-past seven o’clock that evening"|"EMIL CAME HOME AT about half-past seven o’clock that evening. Old Ivar met him at the windmill and took his horse
column2: and the young man went directly into the house. He called to his sister and she answered from her bedroom
column3: behind the sitting-room

column1: 14:00|"two o’clock in the afternoon"|"At two o’clock in the afternoon Alexandra’s cart drove up to the Shabatas’ gate
column2: and Marie saw Mrs. Lee’s red shawl come bobbing up the path. She ran to the door and pulled the old woman into the house with a hug
column3: helping her to take off her wraps while Alexandra blanketed the horse outside. Mrs. Lee had put on her best black satine dress—she abominated woolen stuffs
column4: even in winter—and a crocheted collar
column5: fastened with a big pale gold pin
column6: containing faded daguerreotypes of her father and mother. She had not worn her apron for fear of rumpling it
column7: and now she shook it out and tied it round her waist with a conscious air. Marie drew  back and threw up her hands
column10: what a beauty! I’ve never seen this one before

column1: < 12:00|"before noon"|"There were certain days in her life
column2: outwardly uneventful
column3: which Alexandra remembered as peculiarly happy; days when she was close to the flat
column4: fallow world about her
column5: and felt
column6: as it were
column7: in her own body the joyous germination in the soil. There were days
column9: which she and Emil had spent together
column10: upon which she loved to look back. There had been such a day when they were down on the river in the dry year
column11: looking over the land. They had made an early start one morning and had driven a long way before noon. When Emil said he was hungry
column12: they drew back from the road
column13: gave Brigham his oats among the bushes
column14: and climbed up to the top of a grassy bluff to eat their lunch under the shade of some little elm trees. The river was clear there
column16: since there had been no rain
column17: and it ran in ripples over the sparkling sand. Under the overhanging willows of the opposite bank there was an inlet where the water was deeper and flowed so slowly that it seemed to sleep in the sun. In this little bay a single wild duck was swimming and diving and preening her feathers
column18: disporting herself very happily in the flickering light and shade. They sat for a long time
column19: watching the solitary bird take its pleasure. No living thing  had ever seemed to Alexandra as beautiful as that wild duck. Emil must have felt about it as she did
column24: you know our duck down there—” Alexandra remembered that day as one of the happiest in her life. Years afterward she thought of the duck as still there
column25: swimming and diving all by herself in the sunlight
column26: a kind of enchanted bird that did not know age or change."|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column1: ap 06:00|"six o’clock"|"The supper was to be at six o’clock
column2: in the basement of the church
column3: and afterward there would be a fair
column4: with charades and an auction. Alexandra had set out from home early
column5: leaving the house to Signa and Nelse Jensen
column6: who were to be married next week. Signa had shyly asked to have the wedding put off until Emil came home."|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column1: 20:00|"eight o’clock that night"|"After supper the young people played charades for the amusement of their elders
column2: who sat gossiping between their guesses. All the shops in Sainte-Agnes were closed at eight o’clock that night
column3: so that the merchants and their clerks could attend the fair. The auction was the liveliest part of the entertainment
column4: for the French boys always lost their heads when they began to bid
column5: satisfied that their extravagance was in a good cause. After all the pincushions and sofa pillows and embroidered slippers were sold
column6: Emil precipitated a panic by taking out one of his turquoise shirt studs
column7: which every one had been admiring
column8: and handing it to the auctioneer. All the French girls clamored for it
column9: and their sweethearts bid against each other recklessly. Marie wanted it
column11: and she kept making signals to Frank
column12: which he took a sour pleasure in disregarding. He didn’t see the use of making a fuss over a fellow just because was dressed like a clown. When the turquoise went to Malvina Sauvage
column14: Marie shrugged her shoulders and betook herself to her little tent of shawls
column15: where she began  to shuffle her cards by the light of a tallow candle

column1: ap 11:00|"eleven o’clock"|"While Marie was chattering to the French boys
column2: Amédée called Emil to the back of the room and whispered to him that they were going to play a joke on the girls. At eleven o’clock
column3: Amédée was to go up to the switchboard in the vestibule and turn off the electric lights
column4: and every boy would have a chance to kiss his sweetheart before Father Duchesne could find his way up the stairs to turn the current on again. The only difficulty was the candle in Marie’s tent; perhaps
column5: as Emil had no sweetheart
column6: he would oblige the boys by blowing out the candle. Emil said he would undertake to do that."|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column1: ap 10:55|"five minutes to eleven"|"At five minutes to eleven he sauntered up to Marie’s booth
column2: and the French boys dispersed to find their girls. He leaned over the card-table and gave himself up to looking at her. “Do you think you could tell my fortune?” he murmured. It was the first word he had had alone with her for almost a year. “My luck hasn’t changed any. It’s just the same.”"|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column1: 15:00|"three o’clock in the afternoon"|"As Emil rode homewards at three o’clock in the afternoon
column2: he saw Amédée staggering out of the wheatfield
column3: supported by two of his cousins. Emil stopped and helped them put the boy to bed."|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column1: 17:00|"five o’clock that evening"|"WHEN FRANK SHABATA CAME in from work at five o’clock that evening
column2: old Moses Marcel
column3: Raoul’s father
column4: telephoned him that Amédée had had a seizure in the wheatfield

column8: where there would be sympathetic discussion of Amédée’s case at Marcel’s saloon."|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column1: ap 05:00|"five o’clock"|"As soon as Frank was gone
column2: Marie telephoned Alexandra. It was a comfort to hear her friend’s voice. Yes
column3: Alexandra knew what there was to be known about Amédée. Emil had been there when they carried him out of the field
column4: and had stayed with him until the doctors operated for appendicitis at five o’clock. They were afraid it was too late to do much good; it should have been done three days ago. Amédée was in a very bad way. Emil had just come home
column5: worn out and sick himself. She had given him some brandy and put him to bed."|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column1: 03:00|"three o’clock this morning"|"In the morning
column2: when Emil came downstairs
column3: Alexandra met him in the sitting-room and put her hands on his shoulders. “Emil
column4: I went to your room as soon as it was light
column5: but you were sleeping so sound I hated to wake you. There was nothing you could do
column6: so I let you sleep. They telephoned from Sainte-Agnes that Amédée died at three o’clock this morning.”"|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column1: ap 06:00|"six o’clock"|"On Sunday morning the bishop was to drive overland to Sainte-Agnes from Hanover
column2: and Emil Bergson had been asked to take the place of one of Amédée’s cousins in the cavalcade of forty French boys who were to ride across country to meet the bishop’s carriage. At six o’clock on Sunday morning the boys met at the church. As they stood holding their horses by the bridle
column3: they talked in low tones of their dead comrade. They kept repeating that Amédée had always been a good boy
column4: glancing toward the red brick church which had played so large a part in Amédée’s life
column5: had been the scene of his most serious moments and of his happiest hours. He had played and wrestled and sung and courted under its shadow. Only three weeks ago he had proudly carried his baby there to be christened. They could not doubt that that invisible arm was still about Amédée; that through the church on earth he had passed to the church triumphant
column6: the goal of the hopes and faith of so many hundred years."|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column3: watching the wagons and buggies drive up the hill. After the bell began to ring

column5: then
column6: was not coming. Emil turned and went into the church. Amédée’s was the only empty pew

column8: dressed in black and weeping. When all the pews were full

column15: were beautiful to look upon as they entered in a body and took the front benches reserved for them. Even before the Mass began

column18: ” drew even the bishop’s eyes to the organ loft. For the offertory he sang Gounod’s “Ave Maria

column1: ap 03:00|"three o’clock"|"At three o’clock
column2: Emil felt that he could stand it no longer. He slipped out under cover of “The Holy City
column3: ” followed by Malvina’s  wistful eye

column11: that simple doorway into forgetfulness. The heart

column14: and ecstasy has no fear of death. It is the old and the poor and the maimed who shrink from that brown hole; its wooers are found among the young

column17: and today he could leave her without rancor

column1: 12:00|noon|"WHEN FRANK SHABATA GOT home that night
column2: he found Emil’s mare in his stable. Such an impertinence amazed him. Like everybody else

column8: with no better result. He sat down on the bottom step of the box stairway and tried to get his wits together. In that unnatural quiet there was no sound but his own heavy breathing. Suddenly an owl began to hoot out in the fields. Frank lifted his head. An idea flashed into his mind
column9: and his sense of injury and outrage grew. He went into his bedroom and took his murderous 405 Winchester from the closet."|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column1: ap > 02:00|"After two"|"Frank had been wont to see himself in dramatic situations; but now
column2: when he stood by the windmill
column3: in the bright space between the barn and the house
column4: facing his own black doorway
column5: he did not see himself at all. He stood like the hare when the dogs are approaching from all sides. And he ran like a hare
column6: back and forth about that moonlit space
column7: before he could make up his mind to go into the dark stable for a horse. The thought of going into a doorway was terrible to him. He caught Emil’s horse by the bit and led it out. He could not have buckled a bridle on his own. After two or three attempts
column8: he lifted himself into the saddle and started for Hanover. If he could catch the one o’clock train
column9: he had money enough to get as far as Omaha."|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column4: bringing black clouds
column5: a cold wind and torrents of rain. The old man wore his buffalo-skin coat
column6: and occasionally stopped to warm his fingers at the lantern. Suddenly a woman burst into the shed
column7: as if she had been blown in
column8: accompanied by a shower of rain-drops. It was Signa

column10: for she was the only one of the maids from whom Alexandra would accept much personal service. It was three months now since the news of the terrible thing that had happened in Frank Shabata’s orchard had first run like a fire over the Divide. Signa and Nelse were staying on with Alexandra until winter."|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column1: ap ~ 03:00|"about three o‘clock"|"“Yes. She went away about three o‘clock. I happened to look out of the window and saw her going across the fields in her thin dress and sun-hat! And now this storm has come on. I thought she was going to Mrs. Hiller’s
column2: and I telephoned as soon as the thunder stopped
column3: but she had not been there. I’m afraid she is out somewhere and will get her death of cold.”"|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column1: 14:00|"2 p.m."|"Movies had scarcely been invented in 1913
column2: when Willa Cather wrote O Pioneers! Certainly on the Divide of the Nebraska wild lands
column3: movies existed only in their most embryonic form: pictures painted on thin sheets of glass and projected by a “magic lantern” on the wall. And yet the opening scene of O Pioneers!
column4: by far the novel’s strongest chapter
column5: is completely cinematic in its execution and intent
column6: exemplary of the novel’s gorgeous kind of slowed-down realism. The movie opens with a long shot of the windswept town of Hanover
column7: Nebraska. The camera holds on this “cluster of low drab buildings.” Snow flies against the grayness of the sky and prairie
column8: as this tiny town “anchored on a windy Nebraska tableland” holds itself against the elements
column9: “trying not to be blown away.” And then the camera moves—as slowly and deliberately as the book’s protagonist
column10: Alexandra Bergson—in a tracking shot across the town. We see the frozen
column11: rutted road that is the town’s main street; the “squat red railway station
column13: which cater mostly to the outlying farms: a drugstore
column17: and a post office. It’s 2 p.m.
column18: and all the storekeepers are back from lunch
column19: but except for a few farmers and their wives and horses
column21: hardly anyone is around."|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"

column1: ap 05:00|"five o’clock"|"Marie’s husband Frank Shabata is a violent
column2: thwarted man who will be led by circumstance to do real evil. When we first meet him
column3: he is described “muttering to himself.” He is sunburned and sports a three-day stubble. Cather barely needs to add that though he’s handsome
column4: he “looked a rash and violent man” (p. 78). There can be no doubt about Frank’s character when Cather flashes back  to Marie’s father’s first impression of her suitor: “Why don’t he go to work like the rest of us did? ... Haven’t I seen his mother out in the morning at five o’clock ... putting liquid manure on the cabbages? Don’t I know the look of old Eva Shabata’s hands? Like an old horse’s hoofs they are—and this fellow wearing gloves and rings!” (p. 81)."|"O Pioneers!"|"Willa Cather"
